catalyst.source: The photocatalytic CO2 performance of bulk Bi2Sn2O7 and Bi2Sn2O7 NPs were examined by a 500 mL Labsolar-6A closed gas system (Perfectlight, China).
catalyst.context: 0.5 mmol Bi(NO3)35H2O and 0.2 g PVP were mixed together to dissolve into 15 mL mannitol solution (0.1 M) under stirring for 10 minutes.Meanwhile, Na2SnO3 solution was prepared by dissolving 0.5 mmol Na2SnO33H2O into 3 mL H2O.Subsequently, mix the above as-prepared solution by injecting Na2SnO3 solution into PVP contained one under vigorous stirring.After further stirring for 10 minutes, 2 M NaOH solution adjust the pH value of the solution to 10. Finally, the mixture was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated for 24 h at 200 C.Then the products were washed and dried in an oven at 80 C for 12 h before further characterization. 1 mmol Bi2O3 and 2 mmol SnO2 were dispersed in 20 mL ethanol by vigorous stirring to get a homogenous solution.After drying at 80 C, the mixture was calcined at 750 C for 10 h in muffle with a heating rate of 5 C/min.The as-synthesized product was denoted as bulk Bi2Sn2O7. The morphological, elemental compositional and atomic structural information was characterized by FE-SEM, EDX, AFM, TEM, HRTEM (JEOL-2100F) and aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy equipped with high-angular annular dark-field operated at 80 keV (STEM-HAADF, JEM-ARM200F).X-ray diffraction patterns were collected on an XRD Panalytical XPert Pro by monochromatic Cu K irradiation.The existence of oxygen defects was confirmed by electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy (JEOL JES-FA200 EPR) at 77 K.The chemical states and energy band structures of obtained samples were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (Kratos AXIS Supra XPS with a monochromatic Al-K source) and ultraviolet photoemission spectroscopy (UPS).Bi L1-edge (eV) XAFS spectra were recorded at the beamline 14W1 of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility, China.UV/vis spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Lambda950 spectrophotometer.In-situ Fourier transfer infrared spectra (FTIR) were obtained via a Bruker vertex 70.The surface area and porosity of bulk Bi2Sn2O7 and Bi2Sn2O7 nanoparticles were measured by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K via an ASAP Tristar II 3020.CO2 adsorption measurements were perfromed on TriStar II 3flex with extra-high purity gasses.Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) measurements were performed through a quantachrome autosorb-iQ-C chemisorption analyser to test the CO desorption performance of obtained catalysts.In a typical CHI 660E electrochemical system, electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) was collected in a three-electrode cell with Pt and Ag/AgCl as the counter electrode and the reference electrode, respectively. The photocatalytic CO2 performance of bulk Bi2Sn2O7 and Bi2Sn2O7 NPs were examined by a 500 mL Labsolar-6A closed gas system (Perfectlight, China).Specifically, 20 mg samples were well dispersed into 50 mL water.Before the measurement, the system was degassed and repumped into high purity CO2 with a pressure of 0.08 MPa.A 300 W Xe lamp (Microsolar300, Perfectlight) was amounted as light source simulating solar light irradiation.The test was carried out at about 5 o C and products were detected by gas chromatograph (Cotrun GC2002, FID).The apparent quantum efficiency of CO is calculated via the following equation: apparent quantum efficiency (amount of generated CO 2)/amount of incident photons 100.The carbon source of CO was identified by 13 C isotopic labeling experiment using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (7890A and 5975C, Agilent). The simulation of this work related to density functional theory (DFT) mentioned in the manuscript was conducted using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) 212223 .Projector augmented wave (PAW) potentials were used to treat ion-electron interactions, and the exchangecorrelation contributions were treated by generalized gradient approximation (GGA), specifically, the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional 24 . In the process of optimizing the lattice structure of Bi2Sn2O7 crystal, conjugate gradient algorithm with a force tolerance of 0.01 eV/A and a kinetic energy cutoff 500 eV was used to control the optimization convergence.The Gamma k-point sampling was set to be 5 5 5. To further simulate adsorption of CO2 molecule and other molecular/racial intermediate products onto Bi2Sn2O7, a 22 supercell was built by cutting the original cell along (001) facet, with a 25 A additional vacuum layer added along the z-direction.A seven-layer slab was used to mimic Bi2Sn2O7 (001) surface, with the top three layers free to move, and the bottom four layer fixed.For these surface/radical interactions simulated in supercells, the plane wave cutoff energy set as 500 eV and the k-point mesh set as 331. The DFT-D3 method with Becke-Jonson damping was adopted to include van der Waals interactions for surface/radical interactions. The free energy of all the species in this work was calculated by the formula: where E is the total energy, ZPE is the zero-point energy, S is the entropy and T is the room temperature (298K). For vibrational frequencies calculations, atoms belonging to molecules/free radicals (CO2, CO2, COOH...) were set free to move, while atoms of base materials (Bi2Sn2O7) were fixed.After frequencies obtained, the ZPE and entropy can be derived by the flowing two equations: where h is the Planck constant, k is the Boltzmann constant, R is gas constant, and T is 298K.

catalyst.context: Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed to insight the possibility of CO2 activation on oxygen defects of Bi2Sn2O7 (Figure S1).On the perfect Bi2Sn2O7 surface, CO2 was mainly absorbed in a parallel manner with a length of 1.18 A (Figure S1a).While, after the introduction of oxygen vacancies, CO2 could be adsorbed on the defect site via O1 atom coordinating with surrounding metal atoms with an upright geometry (Figure S1b).The representative CO length of adsorbed CO2 molecule apparently changes to 1.29 A (bottom) with a bending angle of 129. Charge density difference was further carried out to trace the origin of the adsorption behavior of CO2.The electrons neighboring oxygen vacancies could be localized, supplying a high-density electronic state for molecular activation (Figure 1a,S2).After engineering CO2 molecular, oxygen vacancies can serve as the major exchange and transfer centers of electrons, in which the yellow and blue isosurfaces means charge accumulation and depletion in the space (Figure 1b).The back donation of electrons from oxygen vacancies into the C-O antibonding states to activate the adsorbed CO2, leading to the elongation and bending effect of CO bond.As a result, CO2 can powerfully interact with the surface of Bi2Sn2O7 at oxygen defects due to localized charge carriers, facilitating the transfer of photoexcited electrons to absorbed molecules. 17Guided by the above theoretical design, the as-prepared VO-rich ultra-small Bi2Sn2O7 NPs may be a desirable structure to boost the CO2 photoreduction performance. paramagnetic resonance (EPR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were employed to directly characterize oxygen vacancies on the surface.Both Bi2Sn2O7 NPs and bulk counterparts (Figure S5-S7) exhibit a symmetrical EPR signal at g 2.001, which provides convictive evidence of the electron trapping on oxygen vacancies 25 (Figure 2a).It is noteworthy that the signal of the former shows a 532.4 eV corresponds to O-atoms in the vicinity of an O defect.Notably, the higher oxygen vacancy concentration can be observed in Bi2Sn2O7 NPs relative to bulk counterpart, further certified by the atoms (Figure 2d).The notable peak located 1.6 A could be well attributed to the Bi-O contribution 10 .This Bi2Sn2O7 NPs shows obvious lower peak intensity relative to bulk Bi2Sn2O7, suggesting the decrease in the Bi-O coordination number.Based on the above result, it safely arrives that ultra-small Bi2Sn2O7 NPs with abundant oxygen vacancies have been successfully fabricated.The number of oxygen vacancies was considerably increased accompanying by the emerging of coordinatively unsaturated metal ions adjacent to O vacancies, which can efficiently trap photoinduced electrons and reduce catalyst.context: In summary, Bi2Sn2O7 NPs with enriched oxygen vacancies have been successfully prepared via a surfactant polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) assisted hydrothermal method.Oxygen vacancies significantly promote the activation of CO2 and stabilization of COOH intermediates, meanwhile, lower the energy barrier of potential determining step, the desorption of CO.Besides, the ultra-small structure significantly accelerated the speed of bulk charge diffusion.These two factors together contributed to the 8.1 times boosted photocatalytic performance of Bi2Sn2O7 NPs towards CO2-to-CO conversion, in which the CO formation rate can arrive 14.88 mol g -1 h -1 .This study holds significant promise for the design and synthesis of ultra-small semiconductor catalysts with -0457.The broad diffraction peaks of NPs indicate the nanosized features of NPs.Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of Bi2Sn2O7 Figure1e, f, g reveal continuous and ordered lattice fringes with d spacing of 0.257 nm and 0.338 nm, which are consistent with the (029) and(1 1 5) plane of Bi2Sn2O7, respectively.The intact ordered Bi and Sn atoms suggest no metal vacancies formed on the surface.Oxygen vacancies are hardly be directly observed from HAADF-STEM due to Z contrast difference between fairly light O and heavier Bi and Sn atoms.Elemental mapping analysis of the STEM results demonstrate the homogeneous dispersion of Sn, O and Bi elements (Figure1h).Conclusively, XRD, TEM, AFM, coupled with HAADF-STEM together provide solid evidence of the ultra-small nanoparticle morphology of Bi2Sn2O7. Figure 1.Theoretical study and structure characterization for ultra-small Bi2Sn2O7 NPs.Charge Figure 2 Characterization for Bi2Sn2O7 NPs and bulk Bi2Sn2O7: (a) EPR, (b) O 1s spectra, (c) Bi L1- Figure 3b.After the photoreduction test, the structure and morphology of Bi2Sn2O7 NPs did not Figure 3 (a) Photoreduction of CO2 into CO over Bi2Sn2O7 samples, (b) Mass spectra of 13 CO Figure 4 (a) Calculated Gibbs free energy diagram for CO2 reduction towards CO over perfect -1matched well with COOH intermediate, a critical intermediate for CO2-CO conversion.The intensity gradually increased with extended time, indicating the activation and reaction of CO2 molecule.Lastly, the CO temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) analysis depicted that Bi2Sn2O7 NPs exhibited one predominate desorption peak with the same location (around 500 o C) but remarkably enhanced intensity relative to the bulk counterpart (Figure3e).This indicated that it's much easier for formed CO molecules to desorb from NPs surface, further explained the improved photoreduction activity of NPs.On the basis of the above analysis, a pathway for CO2 photoreduction towards CO is presented through the following steps (Figure3f, 4b): 1) CO2 molecules are absorbed on the oxygen vacancies sites.Meanwhile, H2O is dissociated into hydroxy ions and protons on the surface.2) Photogenerated electrons transfer from O vacancies to adsorbed CO2 .3)Subsequently, CO2 -interacts with surface protons and generating COOH intermediate.4) This work was financially supported by Singapore National Research Foundation under NRF RF Award No. MOE2016-T2-1-131, Tier 1 2017-T1-001-075, MOE2018-T3-1-002.National Key RD Program of China (2017YFA0207301), NSFC (21725102, U1832156).The computational work for this article was fully carried out on National Supercomputing Centre, Singapore (https://www.nscc.sg). The morphological, elemental compositional and atomic structural information was characterized by FE-SEM, EDX, AFM, TEM, HRTEM (JEOL-2100F) and aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy equipped with high-angular annular dark-field operated at 80 keV (STEM-HAADF, JEM-ARM200F).X-ray diffraction patterns were collected on an XRD Panalytical XPert Pro by monochromatic Cu K irradiation.The existence of oxygen defects was confirmed by electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy (JEOL JES-FA200 EPR) at 77 K.The chemical states and energy band structures of obtained samples were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (Kratos AXIS Supra XPS with a monochromatic Al-K source) and ultraviolet photoemission spectroscopy (UPS).Bi L1-edge (eV) XAFS spectra were recorded at the beamline 14W1 of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility, China.UV/vis spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Lambda950 spectrophotometer.In-situ Fourier transfer infrared spectra (FTIR) were obtained via a Bruker vertex 70.The surface area and porosity of bulk Bi2Sn2O7 and Bi2Sn2O7 nanoparticles were measured by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K via an ASAP Tristar II 3020.CO2 adsorption measurements were perfromed on TriStar II 3flex with extra-high purity gasses.Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) measurements were performed through a quantachrome autosorb-iQ-C chemisorption analyser to test the CO desorption performance of obtained catalysts.In a typical CHI 660E electrochemical system, electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) was collected in a three-electrode cell with Pt and Ag/AgCl as the counter electrode and the reference electrode, respectively. The photocatalytic CO2 performance of bulk Bi2Sn2O7 and Bi2Sn2O7 NPs were examined by a 500 mL Labsolar-6A closed gas system (Perfectlight, China).Specifically, 20 mg samples were well dispersed into 50 mL water.Before the measurement, the system was degassed and repumped into high purity CO2 with a pressure of 0.08 MPa.A 300 W Xe lamp (Microsolar300, Perfectlight) was amounted as light source simulating solar light irradiation.The test was carried out at about 5 o C and products were detected by gas chromatograph (Cotrun GC2002, FID).The apparent quantum efficiency of CO is calculated via the following equation: apparent quantum efficiency (amount of generated CO 2)/amount of incident photons 100.The carbon source of CO was identified by 13 C isotopic labeling experiment using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (7890A and 5975C, Agilent). The simulation of this work related to density functional theory (DFT) mentioned in the manuscript was conducted using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) 212223 .Projector augmented wave (PAW) potentials were used to treat ion-electron interactions, and the exchangecorrelation contributions were treated by generalized gradient approximation (GGA), specifically, the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional 24 . In the process of optimizing the lattice structure of Bi2Sn2O7 crystal, conjugate gradient algorithm with a force tolerance of 0.01 eV/A and a kinetic energy cutoff 500 eV was used to control the optimization convergence.The Gamma k-point sampling was set to be 5 5 5. To further simulate adsorption of CO2 molecule and other molecular/racial intermediate products onto Bi2Sn2O7, a 22 supercell was built by cutting the original cell along (001) facet, with a 25 A additional vacuum layer added along the z-direction.A seven-layer slab was used to mimic Bi2Sn2O7 (001) surface, with the top three layers free to move, and the bottom four layer fixed.For these surface/radical interactions simulated in supercells, the plane wave cutoff energy set as 500 eV and the k-point mesh set as 331. The DFT-D3 method with Becke-Jonson damping was adopted to include van der Waals interactions for surface/radical interactions. lamp.context: Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed to insight the possibility of CO2 activation on oxygen defects of Bi2Sn2O7 (Figure S1).On the perfect Bi2Sn2O7 surface, CO2 was mainly absorbed in a parallel manner with a length of 1.18 A (Figure S1a).While, after the introduction of oxygen vacancies, CO2 could be adsorbed on the defect site via O1 atom coordinating with surrounding metal atoms with an upright geometry (Figure S1b).The representative CO length of adsorbed CO2 molecule apparently changes to 1.29 A (bottom) with a bending angle of 129. Charge density difference was further carried out to trace the origin of the adsorption behavior of CO2.The electrons neighboring oxygen vacancies could be localized, supplying a high-density electronic state for molecular activation (Figure 1a,S2).After engineering CO2 molecular, oxygen vacancies can serve as the major exchange and transfer centers of electrons, in which the yellow and blue isosurfaces means charge accumulation and depletion in the space (Figure 1b).The back donation of electrons from oxygen vacancies into the C-O antibonding states to activate the adsorbed CO2, leading to the elongation and bending effect of CO bond.As a result, CO2 can powerfully interact with the surface of Bi2Sn2O7 at oxygen defects due to localized charge carriers, facilitating the transfer of photoexcited electrons to absorbed molecules. 17Guided by the above theoretical design, the as-prepared VO-rich ultra-small Bi2Sn2O7 NPs may be a desirable structure to boost the CO2 photoreduction performance. reaction medium.context: In summary, Bi2Sn2O7 NPs with enriched oxygen vacancies have been successfully prepared via a surfactant polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) assisted hydrothermal method.Oxygen vacancies significantly promote the activation of CO2 and stabilization of COOH intermediates, meanwhile, lower the energy barrier of potential determining step, the desorption of CO.Besides, the ultra-small structure significantly accelerated the speed of bulk charge diffusion.These two factors together contributed to the 8.1 times boosted photocatalytic performance of Bi2Sn2O7 NPs towards CO2-to-CO conversion, in which the CO formation rate can arrive 14.88 mol g -1 h -1 .This study holds significant promise for the design and synthesis of ultra-small semiconductor catalysts with -0457.The broad diffraction peaks of NPs indicate the nanosized features of NPs.Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of Bi2Sn2O7 Figure1e, f, g reveal continuous and ordered lattice fringes with d spacing of 0.257 nm and 0.338 nm, which are consistent with the (029) and(1 1 5) plane of Bi2Sn2O7, respectively.The intact ordered Bi and Sn atoms suggest no metal vacancies formed on the surface.Oxygen vacancies are hardly be directly observed from HAADF-STEM due to Z contrast difference between fairly light O and heavier Bi and Sn atoms.Elemental mapping analysis of the STEM results demonstrate the homogeneous dispersion of Sn, O and Bi elements (Figure1h).Conclusively, XRD, TEM, AFM, coupled with HAADF-STEM together provide solid evidence of the ultra-small nanoparticle morphology of Bi2Sn2O7.
